Choices:  A: bushes B: dessert C: books D: heat lamps E: rocks<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>There was a group of children and old ladies who were on a field trip to a restaurant. The field trip took place indoors because it was raining. They were on a scavenger hunt for a vase that was in the restaurant's hallway. The children had a teacher and an old lady that was showing her cat around town. A cat was found after the field trip, which had to be brought back indoors because it wasn't indoor only. The lizards were on the rocks, their home, and on the ground. They are cold-blooded creatures, so they need to absorb as much heat energy as possible.<n><n>### Input 2:<n><n><n><n>The children and old ladies had to walk on the path to the beach.<n>We can see that there is a difference between these two questions.<n><n>### Response 2:<n><n>I am in the middle of a math exam and my teacher asks if I have questions about the math problem I am solving. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:Where do fish spend the majority of their time? Choices:  A: body of water B: lake superior C: underwater D: toilet E: aquarium<n><n>### Response:		The fish spend a majority of their time in the body of water.<n><n>### The question to answer:<n>Where did the old ladies indoors pet cat stay?<n><n>### How can you get the answer?<n>For cat that means that the cat, is in a location that isn't external. So it is indoors. But we are not interested only the location. Because there is many locations in a house, there is many places to put a cat and in a house you can find a lot of indoor things, so you can say that cat stay at the residence, but this would be too specific information to answer for the question. What we want to know is that the cat stayed somewhere that was indoors, not outdoors. To answer for the question we have to search the question until we can find an exact location that is indoors. So for example, we can answer with the choice ''c'', because that choice is the most general and it answers exactly what is needed or what the question is looking for, to be more specific it's the answer the question looks for, so the correct answer is (c), residence. With a (b) or (d) answer would not be the answer what the teacher is asking.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:If you socialize by having trivial conversations it is called what? Choices:  A: make friends B: mingle C: meet people D: small talk E: meet new people<n><n>### Response:		<n>In order to write the responses here, we're going to create a loop with a variable named `letterNumber` and a conditional statement. The conditional statement checks to see which question corresponds to the loop's `letterNumber`.<n><n>#### Let There Be Code!<n>```<n>import os<n>import re<n><n>answers = {'A': 'Make Friends', 'B': 'Mingle', 'C': 'Meet People', 'D': 'Small Talk', 'E': 'Meet New People'}  # add answers<n>word = input("What do you want to know?")  # Ask user for input<n><n>loopFlag = True  # Loop flag variable<n>letterNumber = 0<n><n>while letterNumber <= len(word):  # Loop variable for word length letters<n>    if word[letterNumber] == " ":<n>        letterNumber += 1<n>        continue<n><n>    if word[loopFlag] == "A":  # check for 'A'<n>        letters = answers[word[letterNumber]]<n>        print(letters)<n>        continue<n>    if word[0] == "D":<n>        loopFlag = False<n>        letterNumber = letterNumber + 2<n>```<n>[![Instagram Image](https://img.shields.io/static/v1?label=Check,%20out%20Twitter&message=https://twitter.com/MsHernandez66/status/1326366216272215554)](https://twitter.com/_MsHernandezA_/status/1366930652937604224)<n><n>### Credits:<n>[Github](https://github.com/Ms-Hernandez/Ms-HG-2021-Better-C-Code-Gradebook)<n><n>[Codesandbox](<a href='https://codesandbox.io/embed/charming-https-1fpxn?fontsize=14&hidenavigation=1&theme=dark'><img src='https://codesandbox-user-images.global.ssl.fastly.net/images/project/c220ac76-8e03-4c29-937

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Instructions don't always take the same format. They can sometimes be a conversation, multiple questions, hints, or even have a single sentence or short paragraph with instructions and no hints. This example has multiple questions followed by an answer box. But you can also find more than one answer followed by hints and/or instructions.<n><n>### Problem:<n><n>In this example, the student has been asked to provide their answer to questions they were asked by a friend or family member. Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:What is a fast but expensive way to send small cargo? Choices:  A: airplane B: ship's hold C: boat D: truck E: train<n><n>### Response:		<n>| What is a fast but expensive   |                                          |<n>| :----------------------------- | :--------------------------------------- |<n>| airplane                        | It is a fast but expensive method of    |<n>| ship's hold                     | shipping.                               |<n>| boat                            | boats transport items, are slow but       |<n>| truck                           | inexpensive, and sometimes can carry      |<n>| train                           | cargo over long distances. Train         |<n><n>### Instructions:<n>In other words, what is a fast but expensive <n>method of shipping (airplane etc.).<n><n>### Astronaut's home away from home<n>In addition to having no gravity, astronauts traveling in space (or orbiting the Earth and sun with the Space Station) also have a lack of <n>protection against cosmic radiation (charged particles that can travel through matter at high speed), which is the cause of radiation cancer in space <n>explorers. The International Space Station has built in protection against this risk.<n>The crew gets some protection by sitting or standing in front of the aluminum doors used to protect the crew from micrometeoroids (small <n>meteorites) during reentry into the earth's atmosphere. However astronauts don't have the convenience of just throwing their head in a hole to be <n>shielded. While on one side the doors protect the crew from dangerous meteorites flying through space, on the other side the crew is bombarded <n>with radiation. The solution was to reimagine a part of the space that they didn't know was possible.The doors had to be made transparent, and the <n>crew had to live with the doors shielding them from harm. The astronauts use a transparent plastic shield to protect them from radiation in the <n>same way that a diver's helmet protects against the water pressure. This solution required the astronauts to live in this uncomfortable and <n>unfamiliar environment for the week they are in orbit. Astronauts have to sleep standing up with their feet together and their hips locked together <n>to fit into their new living quarters! <n><n>### Exercise:<n><n>* If you knew that you were being shot at by a bullet that is moving at 600mph, which is

Choices:  A: drawer B: filing cabinet C: computers D: desk E: filing cabinet<n><n>### Response:		A;B;C;D<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:The window across the street was broken and John felt guilty. He never meant to damage what? Choices:  A: friend's house B: curtains C: space shuttle D: front door E: classroom<n><n>### Response:		The window across the street was John's neighbor's window<n><n>### Review:<n><n><n>### What is a computer language, and what makes one a programming language rather than a scripting language?<n><n>Programming languages are primarily intended to be executed at some point, while scripting languages are meant to be read by a script reader<n><n>### Please pick one of the projects and give an answer.<n><n>```python<n>answer1 = python programming question "1:<n>1) In python what are tuples and list comprehension and how are they differ from each other?<n>```<n><n>### What will you do when you have no code left?<n>* check if your code is indented correctly<n>* check if it compiles<n>* print the entire code and check for errors<n>* write the tests and try to run the test case<n>* run the code<n><n>### What's the difference between if and if-else<n>Use the if statement to execute one line of code(statement1) only if 'if' is true. Use else if to execute one line of statement2 if first line is true, else if to execute statement3 and so on<n><n>### What are variables in Python?<n>A variable is a computer memory location that holds a value. Variables are used for both the values and for storing data in the python programs<n><n>### Which variables should you store in the variables class?<n>Local Variable stores are used for simple data and for the variable to be used within the scope of the program<n><n>### Why shouldn't you use any of the following things?<n><n>* If you use a global variable in a procedure (Function) the procedure will override its value when it resumes.<n>* If you use an argument in a procedure (Function), the procedure can change its value without your knowledge.<n>* Functions are used by the compiler to store references to global variables that are defined in the outer scope.<n>* These variables are called local variables, the compiler uses them for the scope of the procedure.<n><n>### What do the arguments of a procedure (Function) mean?<n>When you call a procedure (Function) with more than one argument, you have to specify all the arguments with the procedure (Function) call. You can not omit arguments, that you didn't specify during the procedure (Function)call.<n><n>### Why do we need variables in Python?<n>Vart

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:Where is a snake likely to reside? Choices:  A: tropics B: nightmare C: wyoming D: bushes E: feild<n><n>### Response:		D: bushes<n><n>### Instructions:<n>The teacher asked the class the question and when you answer you have to give a different response.<n><n>### Example one:<n>Question:Where did the astronauts have to pass through to try and reach the moon.<n><n>Answer:<n>Answers: A: sky B: universe C nightmare D: outer space E air<n><n>```<n>"<n>#!/bin/sh<n>echo "Where did the astronaut have to pass through first"<n>echo -e "A: night sky\nB: universe\nC: nightmare\nD: outer space\ne air" > answer<n>echo "$1" |grep'A | ^'>> answers<n>echo 1<n>while read -r A<n>do<n>done < answeers<n>echo "the answer is $A"<n>```<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:In war, your primary method is combat, but your goal is to do what? Choices:  A: conquer opponent B: fight enemy C: join army D: kill E: terrible<n><n>### Response:		Answer: C: join army<n><n>### Instructions<n><br><n>Write a Python script that will evaluate and perform a task. <n><n><br><n>You may use any resource to complete the script.<n><br><n>The only resource allowed are the questions you have responded to.<n><br> <n>Use only that as a reference.  <n><br><n>In the script you must evaluate the questions and then determine the best course of action from the choices.<br><n>For example, in the last question provided.  The response is: C: Join army.  The other answers are incorrect.<n><br> Use comments to help explain choices.<n><n>**This submission must include at least three questions that you can evaluate and then provide an answer based on the best choice.**<n><n>### Response <n><n>##### #1<n><n>```python<n>if(choice == "A: prepare dinner"):<n>    print("Cooking up a storm! We'll all have to sit on the floor to eat but it will be fine")<n>elif(choice == "B: evaluate progress"):<n>    print(f"Good work, let's keep it going. We have been working on this project for awhile.")<n>elif(choice == “C: include examples”):<n>    print("It will be hard to find our example in the text but here it is.")<n>elif(choice = "D:work in school"):<n>    print ("We have worked on this project in school and we have also worked on it at home")<n>elif(choice = 'E: prove their point'):<n>    print("We have prove our point and have won a prize. Great work on this project. Now it's time to start a new one.")<n>else:<n>    print ("Please choose A,B,C,D,E"<n><n>def example(a, b):<n>print (a)<n>```<n><n>##### #2<n>```python<n>if (choice == ''A'': table'':) :<n>    print("The vase is at table.")<n>elif (choice == ''front door'':) :<n>print("Vase is at front door!")<n>```<n><n>### Extra Credit <n><n>**Extra credit is always helpful and appreciated. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: harder B: anguish C: bitterness D: tears E: sadness<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: "Do you care about what other people think?"<n>"No"<n>"What makes you think she wasn't an intelligent woman?"<n>"She did this and she did that!"<n>"Did she do anything to prepare for dinner?"<n>"No."<n>"Well, we don't really know if she was an intelligent woman, do we? Why don't you prove it by starting dinner for everyone?"<n>"Yes!"<n>A: "She felt harder because she had to do everything herself."<n>The teacher smiled.<n><n>### Question(s):<n>What would the husband do if he didn't have to watch children while she worked?<n>### Answer(s):<n>The husband would play with the children.

We next exited the airlock through the airlock, then we entered the other airlock, we then were able to use our suit, our breathing apparatus, and our jetpack in order to reach the space where we could enter our space shuttle for our journey to the Moon." The students will answer that they must walk through the airlock.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:If someone is aloof and self-important, what is their experience when meeting people? Choices:  A: stress B: nervousness C: smile D: being bored E: making new friends<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>1) The teacher wouldn't want the student to make dinner nor evaluate their progress. She wanted them to include examples within the home to show their understanding.<n>2) While in prison you can't have a pet. And the person who committed the crime isn't usually home.<n><n>Therefore, it shouldn't matter were the person was. As long as they know what the word prison means. They should know that a zoo doesn't have indoor only pets.<n><n>They should've been able to answer the question.<n>3) Vases are typically displayed on tables...<n><n>If we think how the restaurant is set up we will find a vase within one room...<n><n>We can't have a vase in the restroom because restrooms have doors, and bathrooms aren't typically found to any great heights. (we can't reach the bathroom from up high).<n><n>Additionally, we can find a vase inside a restroom, however not all rooms could be made into a restroom because of where they are placed within the restaurant.<n><n>The answer doesn't require much thought after considering most of the restaurant.<n>4) To get to outer space we have to pass through outer space. That's how space is. The astronauts don't pass through the night sky, that'd be silly.<n><n>They have to cross the sky within their small spacecraft in order to get through to the moon.<n><n><n>

Choices: <n><n>### Response Choices:<n>#### Explanation :You can find the following listed item in a grocery stores A: shirts B: shoes C: soap D: ties E: underwear<n><n># Tactile Learning<n>## Explanation: I like using tactile learning because students can interact with the materials in their own way. I can have students write in a journal about a concept or have them manipulate objects to solidify their understanding. I also enjoy having students draw what is going on in their mind to better articulate their thoughts in written form. Tactile learning can be incorporated into all subjects/ topics.<n>### Example:<n>Students read about a chapter in a novel. Students are then asked to answer questions about what they just read.<n>### Example 2:<n>Students study 10 states from a region in the United States. Each state has unique qualities and geography. The students are given a project that involves building a puzzle and then drawing the states.The students use their senses to build and observe the puzzle pieces to learn about the geography of the United States.<n>### Example3:<n>Students watch an episode of a foreign television show. There after, they discuss what language/ vocabulary words can be connected to the episode that they viewed. Students can then write the language word in the language it is found in and next to it they write the English translation.<n>### Example4:<n>Students practice the alphabet song in English. One day the teacher sings the alphabet song in Spanish instead. The students then try to change the words to their known English language words and later they are asked to try the song in a different langauge.<n>### Example5:<n>A teacher uses a game during an activity to have students work together to demonstrate their understanding of the concepts she is teaching.<n>### Example6:<n>A teacher has a student describe an object that they see on a table. The teacher asks them to draw the item on a piece of paper for her to look at. The student explains what they can tell about the object. Some students might

Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:What is someone who gets angry after getting drunk likely to participate in? Choices:  A: violence B: falling down C: vomiting D: vomiting E: lower standards<n><n>### Response:		The person is likely to participate in violence.<n><n>### Explain:<n><n>* A: Violence only happens on a nightly basis for someone who gets angry after having several drinks.<n>* B: Falling down happens on a nightly or daily basis for someone who gets drunk.<n>* C: Vomiting happens on a nightly, daily or monthly basis for someone who becomes angry after getting drunk.<n>* D: Vomiting happens everyday for someone who gets angry by drinking some alcohol.<n>* E: Lower Standards happens everyday for someone, not for a particular night.<n><n><n>### Output:<n><n>* The person probably will participate in violence. <n><n><n>### Sample:<n><n>```<n>Input: The teacher wanted to help his students with their math homework.<n>```<n><n>### Response Sample:<n>What the teacher should do to help his students with the math homework: Teaches them a certain math trick.<n><n>### The right answer: A<n><n><n><n>### Explaination:<n>What is going to happen is that the teacher is going to teach the students a certain trick.

Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:If you did well on the test, you might get an A as a what? Choices:  A: see work B: practice C: quiz D: school grade E: homework<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input<n>How is this homework different from other homework? Choices:  a: this homework is no longer homework. b: this homework is not more homework. c: this homework is easier for you. d: this homework is more of a challenge. e: this homework is for more people.<n><n>### Response<n>A: d<n><n>### Instructions:For the questions that follow, consider the words in bold. A: homework B: easy C: different D: challenging E: more people<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:The electric motor powered many important things, including one if almost every house. Name this item? Choices:  A: electric locomotive B: electric typewriter C: multi-coloured walrus D: electric refrigerator E: electric drill<n><n>### Response:		This problem isn't answered correctly. The first three students had to do the math, the 4th student did the math wrong and the 5h student guessed the answer and then wrote the correct answer, but didn't know why he guessed it and had to guess it again.<n><n>### Input 2: The red door is the ____ door. Choices:  A:(n) second B:n first C:a last D:an only E:one other<n><n>### Response 2: The ____ door is the first door.<n><n>### Student Response 3: This is a really simple question! I'll take a shot at the answer and see what happens.<n><n>### Answer 3: This is the correct response! The students were given multiple chances to get the answer, but the students still didn't, but the students were close.<n><n>### Final Answer 4: This is the final answer that was given and the question has been written up so that it is easy to identify which answers are correct.<n><n>### Output 5: Here you can see that I can easily get the output of the function.<n><n>### Conclusion: This could very good at school, the teachers are always trying to get the best answer from their students. This function would work great as an oracle so that we could easily know the final answer very quickly.<n><n>### Sources: This code is from the R documentation for the fable() function.<n><n>---<n><n>### This is the R version of the function.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:If I am a person, I have a unique ability to do what? Choices:  A: cross street B: stand upright C: speak spanish D: speak chinese E: further education<n><n>### Response:		C: speak spanish This is where they need help because they have to say who the students are. But I'm the one teaching the students how to answer like that, so there's no point for me to answer my self<n><n>**Example Output:**<br><n>![Screen Shot 2021-02-11 at 12 35 25 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/80300469/108741010-6c94fe00-7408-11eb-8ba0-3f0f4a29c7c1.png)<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:He waited for his friend at the squash court, but he was worried his friend thought he meant the at the other end of the public what? Choices:  A: country club B: rich person's house C: pool D: park E: fitness center<n><n>### Response:		<n><br><n><n>```javascript<n>var Answer = function(text){<n><n>  let answerText = text.toLowerCase()<n><n>   let answer = parseInt(answerText.trim().replace(/ /g,''))<n><n>if(isNaN(answer)){<n><n>        return "INCORRECT"<n>    <n>  }<n>  return answer<n>}<n><n> console.log(3*1)<n><n>console.log(2*2)<n><n>console.io("Correct")<n><n>let answer1 = 3*1<n>let answer2 = 1*2<n><n>let  Answer2 = Answer(answer1)<n>console.log(Answer2)<n><n>}<n>```<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:Sometimes it felt like being able to pay bills was the only reason he was actively what? Choices:  A: pay debts B: make money C: having money D: making money E: keep house<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: D: making money<n><n>### InputSometimes it felt like just knowing how to do something was the only reason he could do it? Choices:  I: yes A: no II: yes B:no C: yes D: no<n><n>### Response<n>Answer: II: yes<n><n>### InputWhere does the sun rise from and where does it set? Choices: 1. A: north and south B: west and east C: south and north D: east and west E: north and south<n>Answer: D: east and west<n><n>### InputWhy should cops always bring their own water bottles? Choices:  Cops need water when: A: It gets really hot when arresting criminal B: It gets really cold when freezing criminal C: It might rain when chasing criminal<n><n>### ResponseB<n><n>### InputCan it be used when the temperature is below zero?<n><n>### ResponseC<n><n>### InputWhen it is very windy: Choices:  I say yes A: no<n>Answer: I: yes<n><n>## Solution<n>```python<n>def main():<n>    teacher_response = input('What does the teacher want the students to do with their work when it is time to stop? \n')<n>    print('You answered'+ teacher_response)<n>    print_response()<n>   <n>def print_response():<n>    print('A: prepare dinner')<n>    print('B: evaluate progress')<n>    print('C: include examples')<n>    print('D: work in school')<n>    print('E: prove their point')<n>    <n>    answer = input('\nWhat does the teacher want from the students: \n')<n>    answer_correct = get_answer(teacher_response, answer)<n>    if answer_correct == 'C':<n>        print('Example:'+ teacher_response +'\nThe students were assigned a task of drawing an x. they would write down the steps they took to complete the x.')<n>    else:<n>        print('Incorrect.')<n>main()<n>    <n>print('Press \n to see which answer is correct')<n>input('\n')<n>```

Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:I am looking to buy honey right from an apiary, where should I go? Choices:  A: jar B: stick to fingers C: beehive D: stick to fingers E: farmer's market<n><n>### Response:		<n>I am interested in buying honey right from the apiary. Farmers markets are great places to see a variety of honey.<n><n>#### Answer: B<n><n>### Input<n>I love how the teacher can answer the question! <n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a response to the teacher's question about where to find honey.<n><n>### Output:<n>I love how the AAC system can help students communicate!<n><n>### Input :<n>How can the students help the teacher answer questions and take turns speaking?<n><n>### Response : <n><n>I can take turns speaking by using different verbal choices.<n><n>### Input #2<n>I can help the teacher answer where to get honey.<n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: pointed B: bright C: easy D: clear E: acute angled<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>I think that, acute angles, because they are obtuse means they have sharp edges, and a sharpness point, that is easy to do. If you were using a pencil, you can make sharp pencil angles, or with a sharp knife you can cut a sharp pattern. I think that this means you have to be sharp to go to a sharp angle, therefore, it means you have to be obtuse to go to an acute angle.<n><n>I agree with you.<n><n>### Input; You have a long list of things, like groceries, to buy before Thanksgiving. Choices:  A: orchestra B: school band C: music store D: opera house E: home<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Your Code:<n>```python<n>import re<n>answers = ["d", "d", "a", "e", "c"]<n>def my_code():<n>    for index in range(len(answers)):<n>        for question in range(len(questions)):<n>            question = questions[question]<n>            if(question == "Where Did the Old Lady Indoor Only Pet Cat Stay?":<n>                if re.match(answer_regex, question[1], re.M):<n>                    print("You are correct, the answer to the " + question[0] + " question is: " + answer_regex[0].upper())<n>                else:<n>                    print("Incorrect, the answer to the" + question[0]<n>                        + "question is:," + answer_regex[1].upper())<n>            else:<n>                pass<n>            input()<n>               <n>```<n><n>#### Output: <n><n>```python<n>Input:Where Did the Old Lady Indoor Only Pet Cat Stay<n>Question:Where Did the Old Lad<n>Answer:Indoor<n><n>Input:Where Did The Old Lady Stay, Indoor?<n>Question:Where the old lady stay, in<n>Answer:<n><n>Input:Where did you get a bass clarenet?<n>Question:Where did you get<n>Answer:a bass clarinet<n><n>Input:Where Would You Get a Bass CLARINAt?<n>Question:Where do you get<n>Answer:Bass clarinet<n><n>Input.Where Would You Get a BASS CLARINAt?Where<n><n>Input:What Would You Get a Boss CLARINAt?The music store,<n>Input:What Would<n>Answer:A bass clarinat<n>```<n><n>#### Sample output:<n><n>```python<n>Your Code:<n>Your Code:<n>You are correct, the correct answer to the "Where Did the Old Lad Indoor Only Pet Cat Say" question is: "Indoor"<n>You are correct, you correctly answered "Where do you get, a bass clarinet?" after only 2 trials!<n>```<n>        <n>        <n>### Instructs: Complete the Task<n>The teacher asked students to ask each other to explain an answer to a question in more detail. Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:What do you need to have before buying products? Choices:  A: desire B: spending money C: money D: needs E: time<n><n>### Response:		The right answer to this question is C: the money. The question asks "what do you need to have..." The last word, "to", is a signal that the answer must follow the words preceding the "to" in logical progression.<n><n>### Input 2: What is 7 times 11? Choices: 2, 18, 89<n><n>### Response 2: ANSWER: * *   CORRECT *  *<n><n>### Task: What is the next number in the pattern: 0, 4, 10, 16, 22, 28, …? Choices:  0, 1, 2, 3, 4<n><n>### Response3: ANSWER *    BAD *  <n><n>### Problem: What is 5 times -2? Choices:  (4), -10, (1), 8<n><n>### Response4: ANSWER  *  CORRECT *  <n><n>Input:How long can you stay in Australia’s outback?   <n>Choices:   A: at least three weeks B: maximum 36 hours C: up to six days D: for a whole day<n><n>Answer: The right answer to this question depends on what the outback is. An outback is “land that is not suitable to human use”. Therefore we need to find out if this outback has human infrastructure, such as restaurants, hotels, malls, etc…. Since we can live “for a whole day”, I conclude that there are no human infrastructure. It can then only last “up to six days” because you have to live from what you bring from/with you. Thus, the correct answer is: up to six days<n><n><n>### Input4: How long can you stay in the outback?<n><n>### Response5: ANSWER CORRECT<n><n>### Below is a task that describes a problem. Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:What happens when humans are exposed to noises? Choices:  A: pet the dog B: hear sounds C: have sex D: reproduce E: drive cars<n><n>### Response:		<n>D: reproduce<n><n>### Instructions<n>Create an array that has 3 elements.  Set the 0th index to 10, the 1st to 6 and the 2nd to 1. The first element was entered as a number, why it is important to use arrays to do so. Include in the array the elements from the example I gave you, and demonstrate in your work how each data type can be handled with arrays and some of the draw backs of not doing so.<n><n>### Response Instructions<n><n>Create an Array as you described, add them, then use them in an exercise, add the output to the top, make sure what it is what you enter into the array.<n><n>### Output<n>```<n>var input = {<n>  "0": 10,<n>  "1": 6,<n>  "2": 1<n>}<n>console.log(input[0]) // 10<n>console.log(typeof input[0]) // number<n>console.log(Number(input[0])) // 10<n><n>```
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:A large container was a dime a dozen, there were hundreds of rows of them in the giant what? Choices:  A: factory B: garden C: supermarket D: garage E: warehouse<n><n>### Response:		<n>It seems that the question was asking for many words to define one thing, one container. The word “dime a dozen” is a saying meaning something that is so common that you can pick up a dozen for a dime, a coin used in America at the time. The questioner wanted to know where the containers were. Based on the question, my answer would be warehouse. A warehouse has many rows of them because they are used to store supplies for the city and the many buildings in it. They were large containers, they were a dime a dozen because there were many of them, and they were in the giant what?? Well the answer is warehouse because it was the only one of the choices that fit.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:After new coke was discontinued what formula was used? Choices:  A: original B: old C: coke clear D: former E: familiar<n><n>### Response:		C.<n><n>### Input "<n>A: what type of drink are you asking? B: what type of soda is discontinued? C: what type of slogan did new coke have? D: which coke product was released in the 80s? E: which coke product is available now?<n><n>"<n><n>I want the function to output 'b' after it is given 'new coke' as input. The soda to discontinue was coca cola classic but its known as new coke. The new coke slogan 'new coke' did not work which lead to old coke being brought back. This project is to help students know to use logic to help with coding and problem solving to be successful in the future <n><n>It only needs to tell the user if the answer for the question typed is correct or incorrect after it returns a statement.<n>Input: I'm doing great!<n>Output: Good<n><n>It only needs a few to do, that are not super specific and are simple enough so that the teacher can see the students progress if they choose to have a live demo<n><n>### Input/Output <n><n>Input: I'll take one of anything!<n>Output: Sure thing!<n><n>Input: Is that 3 or 4?<n>Output: Yes it is!<n><n>Input: How do you feel?<n>Output: Fine, thank you<n><n>Input: Are you excited for the weekend?<n>Output: Yes!<n><n>Input: What do you want?<n>Output: The biggest mac n cheese option there is.<n><n>Input: How many are on your plate?<n>Output: 6 total.<n><n>Input: What are you eating?<n>Output: The big mac with extra cheese.<n><n><n><n><n>Output: Yes it does.<n><n>		<n>### What should the function look like?<n><n>The funtion should be very basic and simple, just to test if they know the logic behind the function to tell if the user's given response is correct or incorrect.<n><n>The teacher wants to see how well the students know what the function is doing and how well the students can use logic to understand the function. The students should be able to determine if the user's response is correct or incorrect just from knowing what the function does to help them program and write what they expect the function to do. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:James thought that giving the AI a secular upbringing would be the better choice.  He felt that the alternative might have results that were too what? Choices:  A: eternal B: religious C: unpredictable D: holy E: monastic<n><n>### Response:		<n>We're trying to help with your homework, and we want your assignment to be the greatest it possibly can be, so we have to ask you one question: how much time do you need to do well on this assignment? The answer to this question may not seem like the obvious answer, but it's the right one. You can take as much time as possible to do your best work, but if you don't give yourself enough time to do well, then all of your other hard work will be wasted.<n><n>### Input :While going through some of your old papers, your grandmother found a folder that she hadn’t seen in years.  In it was a piece of writing that you were proud to be able to share with her.  What is your grandmother’s favorite kind of writing?<n><n>### Response : Your grandmother loves stories, and she loves a good story.  She especially loves a story that is written by somebody she knows. She thinks it’s important to get to know the writer personally and tell them how they feel about their work.  Because your grandmother is a very understanding person, she is always happy to find out that you have written something that she can read.<n><n>### Question :Your favorite book by ____.<n><n>### Response  :Your favorite book is a novel written by ___.  It is a collection of short stories about a man who is struggling to find out what it is that makes him unique.  In the end, he realizes that his uniqueness is rooted in the people he surrounds himself with.  At the time, he was confused and didn’t want to move forward in his life because he thought that he was the only person in the world who could see himself through the lens of his story.  However, reading the book taught him that although he is the only person who can see himself through the lense of his story, everybody else looks at him and sees somebody different.  In other words, everybody has their own story, and while everybody has a different perspective of themselves, everybody is uniquely beautiful in their own way.<n>

Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:Where would you store a shopping bag if all the seats in your vehicle are full? Choices:  A: the roof B: storage cabinet C: car trunk D: retail store E: home<n><n>### Response:		<n>```javascript<n>const answer = prompt("Answer the following multiple choice questions. What would you do with a shopping bag if you didn't have any seats in your vehicle available?", function (answer) {<n>  if(answer === "A: the roof") {<n>    console.log("You should use the roof compartment to store your shopping bag.");<n>  }<n>  if(answer!== "B: storage cabinet") {<n>    console("You should use the storage cabinet underneath the seats in your vehicle to store your shopping bags.");<n>  }<n>});<n>```<n><n>### Discussion:<n>This exercise, called 'Answer the following multiple choice...', shows how to create a prompt that requires a'multiple choice' answer, and then, after the answer is given, either displays a demonstration or provides an instruction based on which option the user selected. The instruction is displayed in the demo console. And the instruction displays a follow-up prompt that asks the user to enter their response (answers) to the new statement. This is an example how prompts can create tasks using prompts, and how a program can then react to the user's answer.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:When you are expressing yourself by yelling after getting a bruise, what are you feeling? Choices:  A: self pity B: communication C: understood D: pain E: embarrassment<n><n>### Response:		<n>Your response must come from the student so the instructions are written like that. The teacher should have stated the student. I need the answer as part of my response. Also the directions mention the word "emotion" which means this question is one of the answers to an open ended question but the instructions don't ask for the answer to this emotion. I can only think of one to complete the instructions and it is not shown.<n><n>The answer to the above instruction is embarrassment.<n><n>### Input<n>The girl's apartment looked amazing with a new coat of paint, where was she going to purchase supplies for her next project? Choices: 		A: front door B: supermarket C: house D: home E: yard<n>Answer: C: house<n><n>### Input :<n>If you were going with a friend, which of these would you use? Choices: <n>A: door<n>B: front door<n>C: front gate<n>D: front porch<n>E: back door<n><n>The answer would be C: front gate, because that answer is not shown<n><n>### Below is an instruction that describe a task. Write a reponse that appropriaetley completes the request. Then write a second Response, giving another example and answer to complete the request. Finally, respond to your peer’s suggestions and recommend an alternative method of answering the Question.<n><n>## Instruction:  Answer the following multiple choice question and add a second response giving another example and answer. Input: Did you see the rain in the weather forecast? Choices: A: Yes! B: No C: Maybe D: Never E: I live in sunny California<n><n>## Demonstration:  Include the word "weather" and give examples in your answers to your friends question.<n><n>## Sample responses:  You must include the word "weather". A: Yes! It will be sunny all day! B: I can't tell you if it will rain or not. I'm blind.<n><n>## Response:<n>I think the students would be able to recognize their error and know what to do to rephrase and answer it now. At least I would!<n><n>## What did I do wrong?:  I used the word forecast too often in the 2nd question.<n><n>## Alternative:<n>I know how to answer weather questions so I wouldn’
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:What do people who are speech therapists do? Choices:  A: make music B: believe in god C: give speeches D: complete sentences E: build houses<n><n>### Response:		Believe in god<n><n>### Input:"He found himself in the dog house with his mother after finding the last slice of cake under the sofa.". How would the dog feel about this? Choices:  "A: Angry B: Sad C: Unimportant D: Afraid E: Tired"<n><n>### Response:"A: Angry"<n><n>### Input:'What could a doctor do if people didn't believe the virus was real?' Choices:  "There are things that could harm you. A: Believe what is said. B: Think of it as unimportant. C: Think about it. D: Think that it is a virus. E: Think that it is made up."<n><n>### Response:'D: Think that it is not a virus'<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:He had been doing favors for everybody at work, it was frustrating not getting any what for it? Choices:  A: let down B: respect C: illness D: satisfaction E: gratitude<n><n>### Response:		<n>- He had been doing favors at work, but the people that he was doing all of these favors for, made him feel let down:<n>  - (1) They made him feel let down because he was constantly doing things for everyone at his work and they weren't happy.<n>  - (2) They made him feel like they never appreciated all that he had done for them.<n>  - (3) They made him feel used.<n>  <n>### Demonstraiton:<n>- You were invited to an outdoor dinner, where would you sit? Choices: B: The floor C:The dining out E: The table<n>- You were asked to come pick up some milk on your way home, where did you ask to pick it up? Choices: A: The grocery store B: The bank C: The gas station E: Dental care clinic<n><n>### Demostration response:<n>A: The outdoor dining table.<n><n>B. The grocery store. <n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:What could you put a table in if you want the table to be in your house? Choices:  A: library B: demonstration C: corner D: football ground E: rug<n><n>### Response:		<n>**Choice A:** There are a lot of things that you could put a table in such as a library, a corner, outside, a house, a demonstration, and a football ground.<n><n>**Choice B:** A rug is a piece of carpet or fabric that is used to cover the floor of a building or room.<n><n>**Choice C:** A library is a collection of books kept at a school, church, public library or other public place.<n><n>**Choice D:** A house is a place where you sleep, cook, eat, take a shower, and do other things.<n><n>**Choice E:** A football ground is a place, often called a pitch, where a football match is played.<n><n>### Task:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:James was cooking s stew in his apartment kitchen.  Where might he look for a potato. Choices:  A: restaurants B: casserole C: root cellar D: pockets E: pantry<n><n>### Response:		<n>You may have seen people ask to "show your work" on tests or writing assignments. The teacher didn't want you to simply state an answer but also prove your point. You have to demonstrate in detail how you arrived at your answer. So you need to work it out and explain it.<n>The old lady's pet cat stayed at her residence.<n>The vase in a restaurant would be on the dining table but it might not be obvious as the room is likely busy and most people are eating.<n>The astronauts had to get to outer space before they could reach the moon.<n>To locate a potato for cooking, the potatoe can be obtained from the root cellar or pantry.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:The sun was out and the temperature changing rapidly, it was really beginning to what? Choices:  A: drop to zero B: increase C: cool down D: dropping quickly E: heat up<n><n>### Response:		The sun was warming up the earth (Answer A is incorrect because A is dropping to zero and C is also incorrect because C is cooling down)<n><n>### Input : The teacher asked if there was any food left, where was the food at first? Choices: A: on the table B: on the floor C: on the bench D: on the plates E: in the trash<n><n>### Response : The teacher knew the food was on the table (Answer A is incorrect as no food was left by the time the teacher questioned the students in the lesson)<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the questions below.<n><n>### Input Q 1:How did the students find out it was hot? Give two possible ways.<n><n>### Response Q 1:The students probably saw the weather channel and they also figured out as it was very warm and the temperature was changing rapidly. <n><n>### Input q 2: How do you know it was getting warmer? <n><n>### Response q 2:The sun was rising and it was getting warm.<n><n>### How do you know it's getting cooler? <n><n>## Input Q 3:Did the old ladies have to go inside?<n><n>## Response Q 3:Yes the old ladies had to go inside because it was getting cold<n><n>### Instuction: Answer the following short answer questions.<n><n>### Short answer 1:The students made chips, salsa, and water.<n><n>The students used the ingredients they made in their meal.<n><n>###Short answer 2:Yes they used vegetables/veggies because they used peppers and onions.<n><n>They used dairy products to make the "Cheese dip".<n><n>###Short 3:The old ladies went inside because of how cold it was becoming.<n><n>## Instructions: Answer these final question.<n><n>## Instruction: Write at least 5 sentences (one for each letter in the acronym) answering this question.<n><n>## TAGs: ACT-CUE, Questionable, Answer, Input

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:Some might say that if you want to do something that results in changing society then you need to start from within, to do this what would you be doing? Choices:  A: riots B: vote C: change yourself D: social activism E: change clothes<n><n>### Response:		C: change yourself<n><n>### Why? :In this case, people want to change society; if they are wanting to do sometime within that society what they'd be doing is change themselves.<n><n>## Screenshots<n><p align="center"><n><a href="https://i.imgur.com/65iTbLm.png" target="_blank"><img src="https://i.cloudup.com/e8c0FsP5nXZ5/1200x700" width="739" height="415"></a><n><a href="./screenshots/575b32c3a97ed70d6bc1f15a82e8e316.png" target="blank"><img src="./screenshot/575b5262d491fc07bb98bcfec1b1103b.png" width="1200px"></a><n><p>The first screenshot is what I used in the project and the second screenshot is what I had to use when I had to recreate the project from scratch because there was an error in the original project.<n></p><n><n>## Author<n><n>Created in 2018 by David Cervantes
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:What would form on your feet, if you were jogging all day? Choices:  A: heart attacks B: hole in your socks C: exhaustion D: shortness of breath E: blisters<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple choice question?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input:What should you eat when you are sick? Choices:  Gatorade A: B: C: D: E:<n><n>Answer: C: Gatorade - If your sick you should drink or eat something that has a lot of hydration and salt so your body can recover.<n><n>### Input - If you were the principal of a school, where would you hold the most important meetings? Choices: A: classrooms B: hallways C: cafeteria D: gym E: auditorium<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: A: Classrooms<n>Cause meeting with your students, your staff will feel more comfortable to discuss certain problems that may occur within your school.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>If the teacher used the same procedure everyday for how to present their lessons do you think students would become better? Choices: A. Yes B. Maybe C. No D. Most Likely E. Possibly

Choices:  A: city B: michigan C: three feet D: subdivision E: three arm span<n><n>### Response:		<n>Your response should include your name and the school you will be representing at this event. Your response must contain each of these following elements:<n><n>1. A link to you Instructables page with the completed project<n>2. Two pictures or videos<n>3. Three written captions as to what is depicted in the pictures/videos.<n>4. A short paragraph to introduce and describe the project<n><n>Your project must use some material and/or idea from this challenge. Add instructions with appropriate links to sources to use.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The teacher didn't just want the answer and work shown but also for the students to what? Choices:  A: prepare dinner B: evaluate progress C: include examples D: work in school E: prove their point<n>Answer: C: include examples<n><n>Input: Where did the old ladies indoor only pet cat stay? Choices:  A: front door B: zoo C: jail cell D: residence E: floor<n>Answer: D: residence<n><n>Input: Where would you find a vase in a restaurant? Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:What is a parents primary duty? Choices:  A: speak freely B: happiness of a child C: care for children D: school child E: control children<n><n>### Response:		A parent's primary duty is to control children.<n><n>Input:Why do teachers prefer students who work hard? Choices: 	A: they are good people B: they like challenges C: everyone does D: they are easy to help E: they aren't lazy<n><n>### Response:(1 point) A: they are good people<n><n>Input:Would the students agree that the teacher is better at teaching? Choices:  (1 point) If they have learned the lesson.<n><n>Input:What do children like best about their parents? Choices:  B: They are good. Answer: Not hosting a few people in a room. Answer: D: single person<n><n>### Input<n>How much money would a family of five, spending $160 on dinner for every night for a week, spend from their available funds in one week? Choices: 1. $750<n>2. $938<n>3. $1,393<n>4. $660<n>5. $160<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>Input: How much money would a family with five people spend on dinner for every night in a week when they have $160 available? Answer: $938 because  $160 divided by 5 is $32. So $16 and then $32 more each day until the week is over: $32*5 equals $160. 568 and then 568 plus 136 more.<n><n>### Tips<n>

Choices:  Baked them, frosted them, too few  C: too much money, too much energy, too much time D: had problems making them E: the bakers forgot the cake dishes<n><n>### Response_ 1: Choices:  A Baked them, frost them, too few <n><n>### Input2:<n>The two children were going to have a sleepover and needed some snacks to bring along, what two items did they decide to bring?<n><n>### Choices:<n><n>A: chocolate, cookies<n>B: apple juice, fruit<n>C: cake, cupcakes<n><n>### Response2:<n>The children decided to bring A: chocolate, cake<n><n>## Reasons for choosing the solution<n><n>First of all, I chose option C in the first problem.<n><n>### First Problem<n><n>In this problem, the teacher asked the student to describe exactly what needed to be done. The teacher also wants the students to prove their point by describing what they do.<n><n>### Second Problem<n><n>The old ladies were going to put their indoor cat outside and wanted to put it some place it would feel comfortable. They were also trying to get it back on it's feet. In order to make the cat comfortable when outside, they wanted to put it someplace where the cat had experience.<n><n>### Third Problem<n><n>In order for the astronauts to get to the moon and back, they had to travel through the atmosphere.<n><n>### Fourth Problem<n><n>Inflation would cause some economic problems. It would also cause economic instability.<n><n>- [Baked Them](/Exercise2_Baked Them/baked_them.html) - [Not Possible](/Exercise21

Where might she live? Choices:  A: food court B: jerusalem C: new york city D: jewish community E: town<n><n>### Response:		A:food court<n><n>### Description:<n>There were a series of questions asking where various things would be found.  The last question asked where a person would live based on what they owned.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>A kosher deli would be run by a jewish person which means that lilly is probably jewish herself. She lives outside of a heavily populated area which narrows down where she would live.  She owns a kosher deli, which means she's probably observant and living in a heavily populated Jewish community wouldn't make sense since that's outside of her religious tradition.<n>It would be like setting your restaurant in an Amish community but wanting to live in the country side... the two are mutually exclusive.<n><n>Input: In which country would you not find a banana?  Choices:  A : Thailand B: Russia C: Italy D: Belgium E: Ireland<n><n>### Instructions:A:Belgium<n><n>```javascript<n><n>import {<n>    print,<n>} from 'printer';<n><n>// print('the printer')<n><n>print('the printer')<n>```<n><n>### Input & Output:<n>```javascript<n>print('the printer');<n>```<n><n>##<n><n>### Challenge:<n>Input the following:  <n>What does this program say when you input: print("cat");?<n><n>### Challenge explanation:<n>This is a fairly elementary print statement so this should be fairly trivial.  A print function accepts a string as an input and then will print everything that follows it on the current console.<n><n>##<n><n>```<n>import {<n>    // let printer = null;<n>    var printer;<n>    // var printer = 'the printer';<n>    let printer = 'the printer' ;<n>    var printer = ['the printer']; // this is undefined<n>    let printer = ['the printer'] // this will work<n>};<n><n>console.log(printer)<n>```<n><n>##

"The space station has ____miles of steel beams" ____in______the space station is a cylindrical module which is made of reinforced steel. _____<n><n>| **Step 1**: | **Identify the topic sentence.** | Identify the question. |<n>| --- | --- | --- |<n>| **Step 2**: | Rewrite the question. | Rewrite the question in your own words. |<n>| **Step3**: | Rewrite the topic sentence. | Rewrite the topic in your own words. Explain |<n><n><details><summary><n> <ul><n> <li>First example, I got a little confused on step 3, and not sure how it relates. I think it might relate if step 3 was "Include details with words (like, so, for)" but wasn't sure, as I was under the impression I had to describe each subject from step 3, but maybe step 3 is describing what I wrote in step 2.  </ul><n> </li><n> <li>Second example, I thought this was another tougher one as I had to rewrite the topic sentence. I tried rewording the question to something like this, and I then got back on track.  <p style="line-height:28.18px;"> The space station has $miles$ of steel beams</p> <p style="lineheight:28.20px;">and in it is a cylindrical $module$ which is made of reinforce steel $$$$$$$$$$$$$$$.</p> <p> This made rewriting the topic sentence easier as I could rephrase parts of the questions as "How does the space station get up so high? or, How does the space station orbit Earth?"<n> |<n> </ul><n> </p> <p>Maybe the instructions are supposed to be more for teachers.  <p><n> |<n> </ul></li><n> <li><p>Third example, this was the hardest one to me.  On step 2, it would be hard to rewrite the question. On step 3, I think the question should be more focused on rephrasing "the human looked down longingly" to something like "He/she really wanted to be there".

A: Shop B: Floor C: Closet D: Store E: Mall<n><n>### InputWhat is the best answer for the above pair of questions?A: The clothing was not purchased in a closet but an expensive shabby shop. B: The clothing was likely purchased in a closet of a mall or department.<n><n>### Answer <n>In both questions, the answer should be the same. The best answer for both questions is in A.<n><n>### InputHow many pieces of the cake do you want? A: one B: six C: three D: seven E: a dozen<n><n>### Response What is the best response for the above pair of inputs?<n><n>### A: 1 B: 6 C: 3 D: 7 E: dozens<n><n>### Above the question was repeated for all the possibilities and the best response with the correct wording is the one that best matches with the cake?<n>Answers: C) The cake has a dozen pieces, and only six of that dozen were eaten. The remaining six pieces went to waste.<n><n>### The correct cake quantity?<n>The correct answer is in the wordings, "and only six of that dozen was eaten," this means that there's remaining six pieces or slices of cake. Choices:  A: table B: shelf C: cabinet D: windowsill E: bathroom<n>Answer: A: table<n><n>Input: The astronauts were trying to figure out how to get to the moon, where did they have to pas through first? Choices:  A: night sky B: universe C: atmosphere D: outer space E: air<n>Answer: D: outer space<n><n>### Input:Reaching advantage position in a competitin puts me in what position as compared to others? You see all of the colors because you use a light filter, this shows each colored light as a separate shade over top of the others. That is why the last one can't be found in the choice list but it is the least present.
